country.name: Guam
country.background: Guam was ceded to the US by Spain in 1898. Captured by the Japanese in 1941, it was retaken by the US three years later. The military installation on the island is one of the most strategically important US bases in the Pacific.

geo.note: largest and southernmost island in the Mariana Islands archipelago; strategic location in western North Pacific Ocean

location.desc: Oceania, island in the North Pacific Ocean, about three-quarters of the way from Hawaii to the Philippines

area.comparison: three times the size of Washington, DC

geo.climate: tropical marine; generally warm and humid, moderated by northeast trade winds; dry season (January to June), rainy season (July to December); little seasonal temperature variation
geo.terrain: volcanic origin, surrounded by coral reefs; relatively flat coralline limestone plateau (source of most fresh water), with steep coastal cliffs and narrow coastal plains in north, low hills in center, mountains in south
geo.hazards: frequent squalls during rainy season; relatively rare but potentially destructive typhoons (June - December)
geo.issues: extirpation of native bird population by the rapid proliferation of the brown tree snake, an exotic, invasive species

people.ethnic-groups: Chamorro 37.1%, Filipino 26.3%, other Pacific islander 11.3%, white 6.9%, other Asian 6.3%, other ethnic origin or race 2.3%, mixed 9.8% (2000 census)
people.languages: English 38.3%, Chamorro 22.2%, Philippine languages 22.2%, other Pacific island languages 6.8%, Asian languages 7%, other languages 3.5% (2000 census)

literacy.definition: age 15 and over can read and write

government.dependency: organized, unincorporated territory of the US with policy relations between Guam and the US under the jurisdiction of the Office of Insular Affairs, US Department of the Interior

capital.name: Hagatna (Agana)
capital.time-difference: UTC+10 (15 hours ahead of Washington, DC during Standard Time)

government.national-holiday: Discovery Day, first Monday in March (1521)
government.legal-system: common law modeled on US system; US federal laws apply
government.suffrage: 18 years of age; universal; US citizens but do not vote in US presidential elections

executive.head-of-state: President Barack H. OBAMA (since 20 January 2009); Vice President Joseph R. BIDEN (since 20 January 2009)
executive.head-of-government: Governor Eddie CALVO (since 3 January 2011); Lieutenant Governor Ray TENORIO (since 3 January 2011)
executive.cabinet: heads of executive departments; appointed by the governor with the consent of the Guam legislature
executive.elections: under the US Constitution, residents of unincorporated territories, such as Guam, do not vote in elections for US president and vice president; however, they may vote in Democratic and Republican presidential primary elections; governor and lieutenant governor elected on the same ticket by popular vote for a four-year term (can serve two consecutive terms, then must wait a full term before running again); election last held on 2 November 2010 (next to be held in November 2014)
executive.election-results: Eddie CALVO elected governor with 50.6% percent of vote against 49.4% for Carl GUTIERREZ; Ray TENORIO elected lieutenant governor

legislative.description: unicameral Legislature (15 seats; members elected by popular vote to serve two-year terms)
legislative.elections: last held on 2 November 2010 (next to be held in November 2012)
legislative.election-results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - Democratic Party 9, Republican Party 6

government.judicial: Federal District Court (judge is appointed by the president); Supreme Court of Guam (hears appeals from Superior Court - judges appointed by governor); Territorial Superior Court (judges appointed for eight-year terms by the governor)
government.parties: Democratic Party [Michael PHILLIPS]; Republican Party [Philip J. FLORES] (controls the legislature)

anthem.name: "Fanohge Chamoru" (Stand Ye Guamanians)
anthem.by: Ramon Manalisay SABLAN [English], Lagrimas UNTALAN [Chamoru]/Ramon Manalisay SABLAN

economy.overview: The economy depends largely on US military spending and tourism. Total US grants, wage payments, and procurement outlays amounted to $1.3 billion in 2004. Over the past 30 years, the tourist industry has grown to become the largest income source following national defense. The Guam economy continues to experience expansion in both its tourism and military sectors.
economy.agriculture-products: fruits, copra, vegetables; eggs, pork, poultry, beef
economy.industries: US military, tourism, construction, transshipment services, concrete products, printing and publishing, food processing, textiles

exports.commodities: transshipments of refined petroleum products, construction materials, fish, food and beverage products

imports.commodities: petroleum and petroleum products, food, manufactured goods

telephones.assessment: modern system, integrated with US facilities for direct dialing, including free use of 800 numbers
telephones.domestic: digital system, including mobile-cellular service and local access to the Internet
telephones.international: country code - 1-671; major landing point for submarine cables between Asia and the US (Guam is a trans-Pacific communications hub for major carriers linking the US and Asia); satellite earth stations - 2 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)

communications.broadcast: about a dozen TV broadcast channels, including digital channels; multi-channel cable TV services are available; roughly 20 radio stations broadcasting (2009)

manpower.notes: defense is the responsibility of the US
